core.admin module¶

This module is used to register models in the built in Django admin console

core.models module¶

This module contains the database models

class core.models.Community(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Represents communities which are created by organisations

name¶

The name of the community

Type

str

type¶

An instance of CommunityType representing the community’s type

Type

CommunityType

picture¶

Image representing the community in UIs

Type

object

description¶

A detailed description of the the community

Type

str

key¶

A unique secret key used to gain access to the community

Type

str

admins¶

The admins of the community

Type

complex

members¶

The members of the community

Type

complex

features¶

The features which the admins have added to the community

Type

complex

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

admins¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

description¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

features¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

get_community_type_value() → str¶

Get the value of the community’s type

Returns

A string representing the communities type value

Return type

str

id¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

is_admin(user: django.contrib.auth.models.User) → bool¶

Checks that the parameter user is an admin of the community

Parameters

user (object) – A user that is being checked for admin membership in the community

Returns

True if the user is an admin, False if the user is not an admin

Return type

bool

is_admin_or_member(user: django.contrib.auth.models.User) → bool¶

Checks that the parameter user is a member or an admin of the community

Parameters

user (object) – A user that is being checked for membership in the community

Returns

True if the user is a member or an admin, False if the user is neither a member or an admin

Return type

bool

key¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

members¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

name¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
picture¶

Just like the FileDescriptor, but for ImageFields. The only difference is assigning the width/height to the width_field/height_field, if appropriate.

save(*args, **kwargs) → None¶

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

simple_store¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

type¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

type_id¶

class core.models.DataAccessType(value)¶

Bases: django.db.models.enums.TextChoices

Specifies the types of data access levels available in the simple store

COMMUNITY¶

signifies that simple store instance is accessible to every member of a community

Type

str

USER¶

signifies that simple store instance is only accessible to user who created it

Type

str

ADMIN¶

signifies that simple store instance is only accessible to admin and user who created it

Type

str

ADMIN = 'ADMN'¶
COMMUNITY = 'PUBL'¶
USER = 'USER'¶
class core.models.Feature(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Represents features built by 3rd party developers

name¶

The name of the feature

Type

str

picture¶

The picture representing the feature in UIs

Type

object

desription¶

The description of the feature

Type

str

key¶

A unique secret key used by feature developers to access the feature

Type

str

payload¶

The code that instructs the frontend what components to display

Type

str

User¶

The user who owns the feature

Type

object

approved¶

True if the feature has been accepted to be displayed on the frontend by the admin, False if rejected, and None otherwise

Type

bool

core.permissions module¶

This module contains permission logic for objects

class core.permissions.IsCommunityAdmin¶

Bases: rest_framework.permissions.BasePermission

Custom permission to allow only owners of an object to edit it.

has_object_permission(request, view, obj: core.models.Community)¶

Write permissions are only allowed to the admins of the community

Parameters

  • request –

  • view –

  • obj (Community) – The community being checked for permission

Returns

True if current user is an admin of obj Community, False if not

Return type

bool

  • view –

  • obj –

Returns

class core.tests.DataStoreTestCase(methodName='runTest')¶

Bases: django.test.testcases.TestCase

Test DataStore API view

Notes

Implementation commented because it can only be tested with a Postgres database because the model uses a Postgres only field. It was tested manually. Due to Heroku free Postgres server limitation, the test database is SQLite.

class core.views.CommunityViewSet(**kwargs)¶

Bases: rest_framework.viewsets.ModelViewSet

Community view set

Contains API views to perform CRUD operation on Communities

get_queryset()¶

Get the list of items for this view. This must be an iterable, and may be a queryset. Defaults to using self.queryset.

This method should always be used rather than accessing self.queryset directly, as self.queryset gets evaluated only once, and those results are cached for all subsequent requests.

You may want to override this if you need to provide different querysets depending on the incoming request.

(Eg. return a list of items that is specific to the user)

parser_classes = (<class 'rest_framework.parsers.MultiPartParser'>,)¶
perform_create(serializer)¶

class core.views.FeatureViewSet(**kwargs)¶

Bases: rest_framework.viewsets.ModelViewSet

Feature view set

Contains API views to perform CRUD operation on Features

get_queryset()¶

Get the list of items for this view. This must be an iterable, and may be a queryset. Defaults to using self.queryset.

This method should always be used rather than accessing self.queryset directly, as self.queryset gets evaluated only once, and those results are cached for all subsequent requests.

You may want to override this if you need to provide different querysets depending on the incoming request.

(Eg. return a list of items that is specific to the user)

serializer_class¶

alias of core.serializers.FeatureSerializer

core.views.filter_stores_by_access(store, user)¶

Check if the current user has the appropriate permission to access the store

Parameters

  • store (SimpleStore) – The store object

  • user (User) – The user who sent the request

Returns

The store object if the user has the permission, None otherwise

Return type

object
